Posts.Title: excisional biopsy rhodagrl JayeGA

Posts.Content: JayeGA wrote: Hi everyone, this is my first time posting.  I'm Jaye, I'm 56 years young  and I've had cystic breasts for years and have been getting mammograms/ultrasounds every 6 or 12 months. Before now, they came back either clear, or questionable, so I've had more than a few biopsies over the years. There was a new cyst this month and my breast surgeon scheduled me for a needle biopsy. I got the results last week, which was atypical breast cells. She was concerned and recommended that I have the area removed. She also wants me to follow up with an oncologist after the surgery, which is scheduled for next month. In the meantime, she's scheduled another breast MRI (I had one last July) I'm concerned, not just because of the atypia, but because she's listing the procedure as a partial mastectomy, not a breast biopsy with removal of the cyst and the area around the cyst. I'm going under general anesthesia, too. I'm a little worried that it may be worse than she's telling me. What are my plans?  Pray, pray, pray. Try to think positively. And ask for a copy of the actual biopsy report, which I was too stunned to do during my appointment. I thought about delaying the surgery and trying to improve my health, but I think I'm going to just do it. My mother was a breast cancer survivor, and although I know the disease has changed, I still have her courage and my own strength. I would appreciate any kind of positive feedback from other women. Right now I feel very alone. Thanks.  Jaye, ADH dx 4/2012 w/L/Lumpectomy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Atypical breast cells found JayeGA JayeGA

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 03:26PM JayeGA wrote: Thanks much, Sommer43.
Posts.Title: Atypical breast cells found JayeGA JayeGA

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 03:22AM JayeGA wrote: welcome, swimmom!  Glad you found us. This forum is a great source of info and wisdom--in fact brendaks sounds amazingly like my breast surgeon  The info she gave was spot-on. My breast surgeon said the excisional biopsy is important because it gives us a chance to see if there is any cancer in the area, and therefore start treatment early. She also said that some women elect not to do it. They just want to accept the results as benign. The risk there is that if there are any cancerous cells, they might continue to grow without treatment. Her opinion is that it's better to know, than to not know. When I first came to this site, I honestly didn't know whether I would do the excisional or not. I had a lot of drama going on in my life, and it was not exactly a great time to add more to the mix. After getting feedback from other women who had faced the same choice, asking more questions of my breast surgeon, and a consult with an oncologist, (and prayer) I decided to do it and it was a wise choice. They found no cancer (yay!) yet now through the whole process I know much more about atypia, my breasts, good health, and my options. I feel more confident in making the best decisions for myself now, which is far different than I felt just 2 months ago. I would co-sign all the advice you were just given, from the mods, ma111, and brendaks. Make a list of questions and concerns and ask about your options. My breast surgeon made me feel comfortable in asking any questions, and I think you will feel better once you meet with him/her. Keep posting, let us know how you're doing. You are NOT alone.  Blessings!    Jaye

Posts.Title: ADH/ALH Are you doing anything different after diagnosis? JayeGA ED2012

Posts.Content: JayeGA wrote: I'll be meeting with the oncologist this week to discuss options. Just wondering if anyone is doing anything different after their diagnosis? I've basically changed EVERYTHING, and I needed to. I am overweight, my idea of happiness was eating a bunch of sugar foods, I was stressed and worried about a lot of things, got very little sleep and didn't really know how to relax. I liked to walk but did almost nothing about practicing yoga and meditation.  I'm not sure changing any of that would improve my breast health, but I'm going to do it, and would like to know if these thoughts have crossed anyone else's mind? Thanks, Jaye  Jaye, ADH dx 4/2012 w/L/Lumpectomy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: JayeGA wrote: Results were B9!  I'm so grateful!  My deepest thanks to everyone who bolstered me up and gave me support and kind words and optimism during the almost-2 month roller coaster ride. I felt supported from the day I first posted here, and it's helped me see whatever the outcome might be, as something I could handle, and gave me strength to deal with the overall discomfort, breast pain, and endless waiting. Thank you so much! I'll continue to post here, because of my family history, the atypia in the left breast, and my whole dense-breast/questionable cyst history for the last 15 years or so. All the threads on atypical ductal hyperplasia are helpful to me, especially since I have another appt with the oncologist next week, and he'll give my my lab test results and make recommendations for treatment--or preferably, NON-treatment. I don't do well on drugs. I had a hard time tolerating the birth control pill years ago. But I do want to know what options I have.  I'm praying for and wishing for the best for all of us. Posts.Title: Biopsy Today and Scared Ronnie22 Ronnie22

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 07:49PM JayeGA wrote: {{mckenna}} I am so sorry you are going thru this. It sounds like you're doing everything right and your followup was great. With clear mammos and ultrasounds I think most people would feel like everything was ok. Glad you got the mri and are moving forward with treatment, you sound very focused and determined, and that makes a big difference. My mom did a complete turnaround after her bc diagnosis many years ago, she changed her diet, dropped a toxic husband (my dad), changed her job (it was awful) and started walking every day. After awhile, she was singing in the mornings!  She never had a reoccurence (sp) and she's my inspiration. It's never too late to start, and of course, there's unfortunately no guarantee, but it's worth a shot.  Thanks for sharing your wisdom with me--so glad you got treated early!  I would love to hear what exercise you decide to do once it's ok to get started.    Jaye

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 01:23PM JayeGA wrote: It's good to see you again, Sommer! You were a great support to me when I first got here. Sorry to hear you're in more discomfort now. I agree with you not wanting more surgery but I wonder if massage or heating pad or ibuprofen might help with the pain? As of yet I haven't tried much, but your description of fat necrosis sounds exactly like the warm-feeling large lump near my surgery site.  If I reach down and gently massage it, it DOES feel better, but I have to keep doing it. I just hope I don't slip up and do it in public, I'd probably be arrested.  I'm going to google fat necrosis and see if any other remedies might be out there. Maybe a holistic remedy. If anything interesting comes up, I'll post it. Hoping you feel better soon. Hugs, Jaye.
Posts.Title: Discomfort after xcisional biopsy? JayeGA catedamien

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 09:17PM JayeGA wrote: I got a lot from all the responses, thanks! I have been actually massaging the side of my breast every day and sending love to it (thanks Louise Hay) and the heat has reduced and discomfort has too. I took some ibuprofen a few days ago and if it didn't help, well, it didn't hurt. Hard to tell.  My BS put new steri-strips on the incision at my followup visit, and once they drop off I think I'll use pure coconut oil on it.  An irony is that my expensive Bali bra is irritating to that breast, but the inexpensive Fruit of the Loom Walmart bra feels like heaven. I went out and bought another one just because it's so soothing to my skin. Go figure.       Jaye

Posts.Content: JayeGA wrote: My excisional biopsy was exactly 2 weeks ago. I am healing well but still have some kind of pain or discomfort in my breast every day. It also feels a lot warmer than the other breast and I feel like I need to wear a bra, even when I'm lying down. There's a large lump of breast tissue on the left side, and I remember my surgeon saying she made a point to fill in the area where she removed the tissue for the biopsy. I usually end up massaging that side of my breast and it feels better when I do it.I'm chalking this up to the healing process but would like to know what symptoms you had, weeks after your excisional, and about how long they lasted?   Thanks, Jaye  Jaye, ADH dx 4/2012 w/L/Lumpectomy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Discomfort after xcisional biopsy? JayeGA catedamien

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 04:06PM JayeGA wrote: I'm doing well, Sommer...the swelling we talked about has gone down a lot, the incision has healed with a 2 inch scar, and there's a pucker in the side of my breast where the 2 (yep, 2) wires were inserted. I follow up with the breast surgeon in November. In the meantime, I've improved what I eat and exercise every day. I may not look like it, but I'm 60 lbs overweight and it's beyond unhealthy. Had to cut out a lot of sugar, which was good. I'm working on lowering my stress level, which was high.  I'm going to post about Tamoxofen, since the oncologist wanted me to start on it and I've decided to wait. My instincts tell me not to do it yet. Overall, things are well, and I'm very, very grateful.  So there's the update on me! Now about you! What's the timeline for Fri?  Hugs, Jaye
Posts.Title: Discomfort after xcisional biopsy? JayeGA catedamien

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 03:59PM JayeGA wrote: Sommer, I'm not sure of the exact distance, but I asked the radiologist--when he was inserting the wire--if the area was at my chest wall, and he said it was about halfway there.  One area was at 3oclock, another was at 4oclock and they were both pretty deep in. The wire insertion took over half an hour. Do you have some concerns about it?    Hugs, Jaye
